Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Water and Energy Cycle Research and Education from the Stable Water Isotope Budget Near a Tall Tower in the Colorado Front Range
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will observe and analyze the stable isotope composition of water vapor and precipitation, primarily at the 300 meter Boulder Atmospheric Observatory tower. The measurements will be made using an optical measurement technology which has only recently become available, and which allows continuous in-situ observations to be made on a practical basis. Further measurements will be taken of the size distribution of precipitation hydrometeors at the top and bottom of the tower, as well as measurements of the surface fluxes of sensible and latent heat (using a sonic anemometer and a high speed hygrometer) and soil heat flux (using a conductive plate). These measurements will complement existing measurements of carbon monoxide (CO), and carbon dioxide (CO2), and meteorology at the tower, and the water vapor measurements would be taken at the same heights as the CO and CO2 measurements, at 22, 100, and 300 meters. In addition, measurements of the isotopic composition of precipitation and soil water would be taken by students at several middle schools in the region and analyzed for isotopic composition. The middle schools will also be supplied with meteorological observing stations, and students will take meteorological measurements and receive instruction on atmospheric processes and the science of isotope hydrology. The research seeks to evaluate 1) the role of rainfall evaporation (virga) in controlling the isotopic composition and humidity of the summertime boundary layer, 2) the partioning of the surface energy and water fluxes, through isotopic constraints on the transpiration fraction of surface latent heating, and 3) the degree to which pairing water isotope measurements with other gas measurements, such as CO2 concentration, yield improved estimates of gas exchange between the surface and the overlying atmosphere. The measurements will be used to constrain and validate simulations from the Community Land and Community Atmosphere Models.

The isotopic composition of precipitation and water vapor contains a wealth of useful information, including the temperature at which evaporation occurs over the ocean, the extent to which evapotranspiration over land serves as a source for subsequent precipitation (i.e. the strength of the land-atmosphere coupling), the pathways of water vapor transport in the atmosphere, and the strength of trace gas exchange (including CO2) between land and atmosphere. But the multitude of factors determining isotopic composition makes it difficult to extract the useful information, particularly given our limited quantitative understanding of some of the physical processes. Research conducted under this project will thus serve the climate science community by helping to deconvolve the factors determining isotopic composition, and unlock the valuable climatological information contained in it. In addition, the participation of middle school students in the project will serve the general public, including underrepresented groups, in surrounding communities by offering an early exposure to scientific research. Educational activities will also take place at the University of Colorado involving graduate and undergraduate students, including a project in which engineering students design and build a mechanical device to collect rain and snow samples.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The comprehensive study of the water cycle in the Colorado Front Range engaged a range of learners while developing new understanding of evaporation from soils, evaporation of falling rain and the movement of water vapor and other gases in the lowest few kilometers of the atmosphere. Measurements of isotope ratios in precipitation, soil and water vapor were made at a 300 meter tall tower as well as at middle-schools in the district surrounding the tower. The middle-school measurements provided important spatial sampling of the landscape within several-hundred mile of the tower to determine how representative measurements at the tower site are of the region as a whole. Analysis of soil and evaporation isotope ratios revealed that the movement of water vapor within soils, rather than just liquid, is important for correctly calculating both isotope ratios and the evaporation rates in semi-arid environments in models. This highlights a need to improve the treatment of soil water schemes in global climate models. An implication of this finding is that previous efforts using isotope ratios to separate evapotranspiration in to the two components (evaporation from soil and plant transpiration) likely overestimate the transpiration component because vapor transport in soil reduced the ecosystem average isotopic fractionation in semi-arid environments. A version of a Community Land Model was modified to simulate isotope ratios and was used to assimilate data from the tower. Results showed that model simulations of transpiration can be improved to match the observations when the isotope measurements are used as a constraint along-side water fluxes, and surface energy balance. The result was further refined adding carbon dioxide flux measurements to the calculation to constrain the transpiration rate, which exploits the similarity of photosynthesis and transpiration that both depend on leaf stomata. Measurements of isotope ratios of rainfall were made continuously over the project and also during a series of rainfall events to evaluate the way in which evaporation of falling raindrops influences the final isotope ratios of water collected at the ground. A robotic rain water collector was developed and built by students as part of an engineering project. The unit was deployed to enable automatic rain water samples to be collected every few minutes during a rain storm. The isotopic ratios of these samples revealed that there are two different mechanisms by which isotope ratios become enriched: the first in associated with stratiform rain falling though mostly undisturbed boundary layers, and the second in concert with thuderstorms that produced wind gusts from downdrafts ahead of the main rainfall. In the case of the latter, isotope ratios showed distinct fractionation effects during the first 15-30 minutes of rain storms. In the case of the latter, rain water isotope ratios more closely resembled the water vapor of the downdraft air. The contrast between these two types of rain storms shows that global scale models must capture the time evolution of rain in spatial confined regions of downdrafts to correctly simulate the isotope ratios of rainfall. The linkage between observations, process studies, and the modeling outcomes was the subject of a doctoral thesis completed as part of this project.

Over the course of the project, students and teachers at eleven middle-schools who helped with making measurements also made use of a new multi-lesson curriculum package, named “Water-Spotters”, which both met State of Colorado Science Standards and engaged students from a broad range of backgrounds in regional and global water and climate science. The class modules cover a range of hands-on activities to encourage experiential learning. Teachers used the material both during scheduled classes and as part of after-school MESA (Math Engineering Science Achievement) programs. Teachers undertook a series of professional development activities, in the form of training with the curriculum material, visits and lectures at the University of Colorado, and working with project Principal Investigator and graduate students who visited their classrooms during school visits. During the project several undergraduate students assisted in research tasks both in the field and laboratory settings.
